objectives: Learn simple ways to greet others and say your name.
Practice sharing basic information about yourself, like your village and class.
Build confidence to speak in English with others.

topics.title: 1. Starting Your Introduction: Greetings and Name

sections.text: When you meet someone, you first say 'Hello' or 'Hi'. This shows you are friendly and ready to talk. The greeting can change based on the time of day.

examples.label: Hello
examples.value: A common and polite way to start a conversation with anyone, any time.

examples.label: Hi
examples.value: A more casual and friendly way to greet people you know well, like friends or classmates.

examples.label: Good morning
examples.value: Use this greeting from sunrise until noon (12:00 PM).

examples.label: Good afternoon
examples.value: Use this greeting from noon (12:00 PM) until evening (around 5:00 PM).

examples.label: Good evening
examples.value: Use this greeting from evening (around 5:00 PM) until night (before sleeping).

usage_examples: **Hello**, how are you?
**Hi**, Rahul! What are you doing?
**Good morning**, teacher!
**Good afternoon**, everyone in the classroom.
**Good evening**, uncle and auntie.
**Hello**, my new friend.
**Good morning**, sun!

sections.text: After greeting, the most important step is to tell your name. This helps others know who you are. You can use 'My name is...' or 'I am...'.

examples.label: My name is...
examples.value: A formal and complete way to state your name.

examples.label: I am...
examples.value: A shorter and more direct way to state your name.

examples.label: You can call me...
examples.value: Use this if you have a nickname or prefer a shorter version of your name.

usage_examples: Hello, **my name is Ram**.
Hi, **I am Sita**.
Good morning, **my name is Priya**.
I am Rahul, and **you can call me Rahul**.
My name is Anand. What is your name?
Hello, I am Deepa, a student from this village.
Good evening, I am your new neighbor, Suresh.

sections.text: Tell people where you live or where your home is. This helps them understand your background.

examples.label: I am from...
examples.value: Use this to state your village or town.

examples.label: I live in...
examples.value: Use this to state the name of your village.

examples.label: Our village is called...
examples.value: A way to introduce your village.

usage_examples: I am Ram. **I am from Shantipur village**.
My name is Priya. **I live in Basantpur**.
Hello, I am Ganesh. **Our village is called Kherwadi**.
We are from a small village near the river.
I am from a farming family in this village.
What village are you from?
My home is in this beautiful village.

sections.text: Tell others which class you study in and the name of your school. This is important when meeting new classmates or teachers.

examples.label: I study in class...
examples.value: State your current class or standard.

examples.label: I am in class...
examples.value: Another way to state your class.

examples.label: My school is...
examples.value: State the name of your school.

examples.label: I go to...
examples.value: Used to say which school you attend.

usage_examples: I am Sita. **I study in class 6**.
My name is Rohan. **I am in class 8 at Government High School**.
Hello, I am Pooja. **My school is the local Zilla Parishad school**.
I go to school in the next village.
We study in the same class.
Which class are you in?
My brother studies in class 10.

sections.text: You can also talk about your family members and what they do. This gives a little more information about your daily life.

examples.label: My father is a...
examples.value: Tell about your father's profession.

examples.label: My mother is a...
examples.value: Tell about your mother's profession or role at home.

examples.label: I have one brother/sister.
examples.value: Share information about your siblings.

examples.label: We are a farming family.
examples.value: A simple way to describe your family's main work.

usage_examples: My name is Arjun. **My father is a farmer**.
I am Lakshmi. **My mother is a homemaker and helps in the fields**.
I have an **elder brother and a younger sister**.
We are a **farming family**, and we grow rice.
My father is a **shopkeeper** in the village.
My mother sells milk in the market.
I live with my **grandparents and parents**.

sections.text: You can share what you like to do in your free time. This makes your introduction more personal and interesting.

examples.label: I like to...
examples.value: Express your favorite activities.

examples.label: My hobby is...
examples.value: Another way to talk about your favorite pastime.

examples.label: I enjoy...
examples.value: A more advanced way to express liking something.

usage_examples: Hello, I am Ravi. **I like to play cricket**.
My name is Geeta. **My hobby is drawing pictures**.
I am a student. **I enjoy reading storybooks**.
In the evenings, I like to help my father on the farm.
I enjoy listening to music and singing folk songs.
My hobby is collecting stamps.
What do you like to do in your free time?

sections.text: When you introduce yourself, speak slowly and clearly. Don't rush. This helps others understand you easily and makes you feel more confident.

examples.label: Speak Slowly
examples.value: Take your time with each word. Don't rush.

examples.label: Speak Clearly
examples.value: Open your mouth well and make sure each sound is heard.

examples.label: Practice Pronunciation
examples.value: Say new words many times until they feel easy on your tongue.

usage_examples: **Speak slowly**, so everyone can understand your name.
Try to **speak clearly** when you introduce yourself.
Let's **practice pronunciation** of village names.
Take a deep breath before you speak.
It's okay to make mistakes; just try again and speak clearly.
Your voice is clear and easy to understand.

sections.text: Practice introducing yourself with your friends, classmates, or family members. You can pretend to meet new people. This is called 'role-play'. The more you practice, the more confident you will become.

examples.label: Partner Practice
examples.value: One student introduces, the other listens and then introduces themselves.

examples.label: Circle Introduction
examples.value: Everyone sits in a circle and introduces themselves one by one.

examples.label: Role-play New Friend
examples.value: Pretend you meet a new friend at the village fair and introduce yourself.

usage_examples: Let's do a **partner introduction** exercise.
In our **circle introduction**, everyone will say their name and village.
Today, we will **role-play** meeting a new teacher.
Practice helps you speak without fear.
Listen carefully when your friend introduces themselves.
We can practice our introductions every day after school.
